questions.content: A volume of 50.00 mL of a weak acid of unknown concentration is titrated with 0.10 M solution of NaOH. The equivalence point is reached after 39.30 mL of NaOH solution has been added. At the half equivalence point (19.65 mL) the pH is 4.85. Thus, initial concentration of the acid and its pKa values are

options.content:
$$[HA]$$ $$p{K_a}$$
0.1 M 4.85

$$[HA]$$ $$p{K_a}$$
0.079 M 4.85

$$[HA]$$ $$p{K_a}$$
0.1 M 3.70

$$[HA]$$ $$p{K_a}$$
0.097 M 2.93

questions.explanation:
From molarity equation,

M1V1 = M2V2

M1 $$\times$$ 50.0 = 0.10 $$\times$$ 39.30

$$\therefore$$ $${M_1} = {{0.10 \times 39.30} \over {50}} = 0.0786$$ M

When half equivalence point is reached,

$$[HA] = [{A^ - }]$$

$$pH = p{K_a} + \log {{[{A^ - }]} \over {[HA]}}$$

$$pH = p{K_a} = 4.85$$

questions.content: A solution of copper sulphate is electrolyzed between copper electrodes by a current of 10.0A passing for one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the changes occur at the electrodes and in the solution?

options.content: 11.84 g of copper will deposit on the cathode
11.84 g of copper will deposit on the anode
11.84 g of copper will deposit on the anode as well as on the cathode
copper will not deposit on any  of the electrode

questions.explanation:
According to Faraday's first law of electrolysis:

The reaction at cathode : $$\mathop {C{u^{2 + }}}\limits_{63.5\,g} + 2{e^ - } \to \mathop {Cu}\limits_{2 \times 96500C} $$

The quantity of charge passed

= I $$\times$$ t = (10 amp) $$\times$$ (60 $$\times$$ 60s) = 36000 C.

2 $$\times$$ 96500 C of charge deposit copper - 63.5 g

36000 C of charge deposit copper

$$ = {{(63.5\,g)} \over {(2 \times 96500\,C)}} \times (36000C)$$ = 11.84 g

Thus, 11.84 g of copper will dissolve from the anode and the same amount from the solution will get deposited on the cathode. The concentration of the solution will remain unchanged.

questions.content: At the top of a mountain the thermometer reads 0$$^\circ$$C and the barometer reads 710 mm Hg. At the bottom of the mountain the temperature is 30$$^\circ$$C and the pressure is 760 mm Hg. The ratio of the density of air at the top to that of the bottom is
questions.explanation:
At top of a mountain,

T1 = 0 + 273 K, $${p_1} = {{710} \over {760}}$$ atm and density = $$\rho$$1

At bottom of mountain,

T2 = 303 K, p2 = 1 atm and density = $$\rho$$2

$$\because$$ $$pV = {w \over M}RT$$ or $$p = \rho {{RT} \over M}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{{\rho _1}} \over {{\rho _2}}} = {{{p_1}} \over {{T_1}}} \times {{{T_2}} \over {{p_2}}}$$

or, $${{{\rho _1}} \over {{\rho _2}}} = {{710/760 \times 303} \over {273 \times 1}} = {{1.04} \over 1}$$

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The enthalpies of combustion of carbon and carbon monoxide in excess of oxygen at 298 K and constant pressure are $$-$$393.5 kJ/mol and $$-$$280.0 kj/mol respectively. The heat of formation of carbon monoxide at constant volume is
questions.explanation:
Heat change at constant pressure means enthalpy change ($$\Delta$$rH = qp).

Heat of formation of CO is written as:

$$C(s) + {1 \over 2}{O_2}(g) \to CO(g)$$; $${\Delta _f}{H^\Theta }$$ = ?

Now, we have,

I. $$C(g) + {O_2}(g) \to C{O_2}(g)$$; $${\Delta _c}H_1^\Theta $$ = $$-$$393.5 kJ/mol

II. $$CO(g) + {1 \over 2}{O_2}(g) \to C{O_2}(g)$$; $${\Delta _c}H_2^\Theta $$ = $$-$$ 283 kJ/mol

Substracting appropriately (i.e. I-II), we get,

$$C(s) + {1 \over 2}{O_2}(g) \to CO(g)$$; $${\Delta _f}H_{}^\Theta $$

From Hess's law, $${\Delta _f}H_{}^\Theta = {\Delta _c}H_1^\Theta - {\Delta _c}H_2^\Theta $$

$$ \Rightarrow {\Delta _f}H_{}^\Theta = - 393.5 - ( - 283) = 110.5$$ kJ/mol

Now, calculation of the heat of formation at constant volume means that we have to calculate change in internal energy (i.e. $$\Delta$$rU)

Using, $${\Delta _r}H = {\Delta _r}U + p\Delta V$$ [For a chemical reaction]

$$ = {\Delta _r}U + \Delta {n_g}RT$$ [As pV = nRT]

[$$\Delta$$ng = gaseous moles of products $$-$$ gaseous moles of reactant]

$$ \Rightarrow {\Delta _r}U = {\Delta _r}H - \Delta {n_g}RT$$

Now, putting the values : $$\Delta {n_g} = 1 - {1 \over 2} = {1 \over 2}$$, T = 298 K,

R = 8.314 J/K/mol and $${\Delta _f}{H^\Theta }$$ = $$-$$110.5 kJ/mol

$$ \Rightarrow {\Delta _f}{H^\Theta } = - 110.5 - {1 \over 2} \times 8.314 \times 2.98 \times {10^{ - 3}}$$

= $$-$$111.7 kJ/mol

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Following statements regarding the periodic trends of chemical reactivity to the alkali metals and the halogens are given. Which of these statements gives the correct picture?

options.content: The reactivity decreases in the alkali metals but increases in the halogens with increase in atomic number down the group.
In both the alkali metals and the halogens the chemical reactivity decreases with increase in atomic number down the group
Chemical reactivity increases with increase in atomic number down the group in both the alkali metals and halogens.
In alkali metals the reactivity increases but in the halogens it decreases with increase in atomic number down the group.

questions.explanation:
The correct option describing the trend for chemical reactivity within the group for alkali metals and halogens is Option D.

Here is the explanation for the periodic trends in reactivity for alkali metals and halogens:

Alkali Metals (Group 1 elements): For alkali metals, the chemical reactivity increases with an increase in atomic number down the group. This is because alkali metals have only one electron in their outermost shell, and the ease with which this electron is lost (their ionization energy) decreases as the size of the atoms increases down the group. Larger atoms have the valence electron further from the nucleus, which results in less electrostatic attraction between the nucleus and the electron. Therefore, the electron can be removed more easily, making the atom more reactive. As a result, cesium and francium are the most reactive alkali metals.

Halogens (Group 17 elements): For halogens, the chemical reactivity decreases with an increase in atomic number down the group. Halogens have seven electrons in their outermost shell and are one electron short of a full octet. They tend to gain an electron to achieve a stable electronic configuration. The ability to attract an electron is known as electronegativity, which typically decreases down the group as the size of atoms increase and the added inner electron shells shield the outer electrons from the pull of the nucleus. Thus, fluorine is the most reactive halogen, being able to attract electrons more easily than other halogens like chlorine, bromine, and iodine.

Therefore, Option D is correct: "In alkali metals the reactivity increases but in the halogens it decreases with increase in atomic number down the group."

questions.content:
A(g) $$\to$$ P(g) + Q(g) + R(g),

Follow first order kinetics with a half-life of 69.3 s at 500$$^\circ$$C. Starting from the gas 'A' an container at 500$$^\circ$$C and at a pressure of 0.4 atm, the total pressure of the system after 230 s will be
questions.explanation:
Pt = 0.4 $$-$$ x + x + x + x = 0.4 + 2x or x = $${{{P_t} - 0.4} \over 2}$$

PA = P0 $$-$$ x = P0 $$-$$ $${{{P_t} - 0.4} \over 2}$$ = $${{2 \times 0.4 - {P_t} + 0.4} \over 2} = {{1.2 - {P_t}} \over 2}$$

From, $$k = {{2.303} \over t}\log {{{P_0}} \over {{P_A}}}$$

$${{0.693} \over {{t_{1/2}}}} = {{2.303} \over {230}}\log \left( {{{0.4 \times 2} \over {1.2 - {P_t}}}} \right)$$

$${{0.693} \over {{t_{1/2}}}} = {{2.303} \over {230}}\log \left( {{{0.8} \over {1.2 - {P_t}}}} \right)$$

$$\log {{0.8} \over {1.2 - {P_t}}} = {{0.693 \times 230} \over {69.3 \times 2.303}} = 0.9987$$

$${{0.8} \over {1.2 - {P_t}}} = {10^{0.9987}}$$

$$0.8 = (10)(1.2 - {P_t})$$

$$0.8 = 12 - 10{P_t}$$

$$10{P_t} = 12 - 0.8$$

$$10{P_t} = 11.2$$

$${P_t} = {{11.2} \over {10}} = 1.12$$ atm

questions.content:
Titration of 0.1467 g of primary standard Na2C2O4 required 28.85 mL of KMnO4

solution. Calculate the molar concentration of KMnO4 solution.
questions.explanation:
5C2O$$_4^{2 - }$$ + 2MnO$$_4^{ - }$$ + 16H+ $$\to$$ 2Mn2+ + 10CO2 + 8H2O

Note In a reaction (redox/neutralisation) number of equivalents of different reactants are same.

Equivalents of C2O$$_4^{2 - }$$ = Equivalents of MnO$$_4^{- }$$

Equivalent weight of C2O$$_4^{2 - }$$ = $${{Molecular\,weight} \over 2}$$

$$\therefore$$ Molarity = 2 $$\times$$ Normality

Equivalent weight of MnO$$_4^{ - }$$ = $${{Molecular\,weight} \over 5}$$

Molarity = 5 $$\times$$ Normality

Number of equivalents of MnO$$_4^{- }$$ = $${{28.85 \times 5\,{M_1}} \over {1000}}$$

Number of equivalents of Na2C2O$$_4^{- }$$ = $${{0.1467} \over {67}}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{28.85 \times 5\,{M_1}} \over {1000}} - {{0.1467} \over {67}}$$

M1 = 0.01518 M

questions.content: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the complex [Cr(NH3)6]Cl3.

options.content: The complex involves d<sup>2</sup>sp<sup>3</sup> hybridisation and its octahedral in shape.
The complex is an outer orbital complex.
The complex gives white precipitate with silver nitrate solution.

questions.explanation:
$$\underbrace {[Cr{{(N{H_3})}_6}]}_{Coordination\,sphere}\,\,\underbrace {C{l_3}}_{Ionisable}$$ $$\rightleftharpoons$$ $${[Cr{(N{H_3})_6}]^{3 + }} + 3C{l^ - }$$

$$[Cr{(N{H_3})_6}]C{l_3}\buildrel {AgN{O_3}} \over \longrightarrow \mathop {AgCl \downarrow }\limits_{(White\,ppt.)} $$

Config. of Cr (24) = 3d5 4s1

Config. Cr3+ = 3d3 4s0

Thus option (d) is correct.

(a) d2sp3 hybridisation, octahedral. Thus, option (a) is correct.

(b) here are three unpaired electrons, hence it is paramagnetic. Thus, option (b) is correct.

(c) d2sp3 inner orbital complex. Thus option (c) is as incorrect.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content:
Find out the wrong number.

2, 6, 12, 72, 865, 62208
questions.explanation:
To find the wrong number in the sequence, we need to look for some pattern that the other numbers follow which the wrong number does not. Let's examine the sequence given:

2, 6, 12, 72, 865, 62208

At first glance, there doesn't seem to be a simple arithmetic progression or geometric progression. Therefore, we need to look for alternative patterns. One method is to examine the ratios of successive terms to see if they follow a certain pattern:

  • 6 / 2 = 3
  • 12 / 6 = 2
  • 72 / 12 = 6
  • 865 / 72 12.01
  • 62208 / 865 71.91

The pattern isn't immediately clear from these ratios. Another approach is to look at how each number could be generated from the previous one using any mathematical operations (such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, powers, factorials, etc.). A more complex pattern may involve factorials or powers, given how the numbers increase rapidly. But looking at the jumps between the numbers, another idea might be to examine multiplicative factors increased by non-constant additive increments:

  • The jump from 2 to 6 is by multiplying by 3 (2 * 3).
  • The jump from 6 to 12 is by multiplying by 2 (6 * 2).

If the pattern is based on multiplying by natural numbers and each time we increase the multiplier by 1, we would expect:

2 (multiplied by 3) = 6

6 (multiplied by 2) = 12

12 (multiplied by 3) should be 36, but we have 72.

At this stage, there is a clear discrepancy since 72 is not obtainable by multiplying 12 by 3. Let's continue to see if there is a different pattern:

12 (multiplied by 6) = 72

72 (multiplied by 12) = 864

According to the second part of the pattern, the term after 72 should be 864 if we multiply by 12. But instead, we have 865. This suggests that 865 is the number that does not fit in the pattern. We would expect a multiplication sequence by consecutive natural numbers (2, 3, 4, ...) or some similar pattern. Either way, 865 is incorrect because it is one more than what the pattern suggests (864).

Given the choices:

  • Option A: 72 - This fits with our pattern when using a multiplier of 6.
  • Option B: 12 - This fits with our pattern when using a multiplier of 2.
  • Option C: 62208 - It doesnt fit the pattern if we extend it, but keep in mind 865 is already incorrect and should be 864.
  • Option D: 865 - This number is one more than what the pattern suggests, so it is the incorrect number in the sequence.

Therefore, the answer is:

Option D: 865

questions.content: Let f(x) = x $$-$$ 3, g(x) = 4 $$-$$ x. Then the set of values of x for which $$|f(x) + g(x)|\, < \,|f(x)| + |g(x)|$$ is true, is given by :
questions.explanation:
The given inequality is equivalent to

$$1 < |x - 3| + |4 - x|$$

i.e., $$1 < |x - 3| + |x - 4|$$ ...... (i)

For x < 3, we have

$$3 - x + 4 - x = 7 - 2x > 1$$

i.e., x < 3, which is true in the domain.

For $$3 \le x < 4$$, Eq. (i) gives

$$x - 3 + 4 - x = 1 < 1$$ ..... (ii)

For 4 $$\le$$ x, we have

$$2x - 7 > 1 \Rightarrow x > 4$$ ...... (iii)

From Eqs. (i) and (iii), we have the solution of the inequality as x < 3 or x > 4.

i.e., $$x \in ] - \infty ,3) \cup (4,\infty $$ [which is equal to R $$-$$ [3, 4].

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The solution of the equation $${{dy} \over {dx}} + {1 \over x}\tan y = {1 \over {{x^2}}}\tan y\sin y$$ is
questions.explanation:
We have, $${{dy} \over {dx}} + {{\tan y} \over x} = {{\tan y\sin y} \over {{x^2}}}$$

Now, divide by tan y sin y both sides, we get

$$\cot y\cos ec\,y{{dy} \over {dx}} + {{\cos ec\,y} \over x} = {1 \over {{x^2}}}$$ ...... (i)

Put cosec y = z

$$\therefore$$ $$ - \cos ec\,y\cot y{{dy} \over {dx}} = {{dz} \over {dx}}$$

$$\therefore$$ Eq. (i) reduces to

$${{dz} \over {dx}} - {z \over x} = - {1 \over {{x^2}}}$$

$$IF = {e^{\int { - {1 \over x}dx} }} = {e^{ - \log x}} = {1 \over x}$$

Hence solution is

$${z \over x} = \int { - {1 \over {{x^3}}}dx = {1 \over {2{x^2}}} + c} $$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {x\sin y}} = {{1 - 2c{x^2}} \over {2{x^2}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2x = \sin y{(1 - 2cx)^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2x = \sin y(1 - 2c{x^2})$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The value of the definite integral $$\int\limits_0^{\pi /2} {{{dx} \over {\tan x + \cot x + \cos ec\,x + \sec x}}} $$
questions.explanation:
We have,

$$I = \int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {{{dx} \over {\tan x + \cot x + \cos ec\,x + \sec x}}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = \int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {{{dx} \over {{{\sin x} \over {\cos x}} + {{\cos x} \over {\sin x}} + {1 \over {\sin x}} + {1 \over {\cos x}}}}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = \int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {{{\sin x\cos xdx} \over {1 + \sin x + \cos x}}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = \int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {{{2\sin {x \over 2}\cos {x \over 2}\left( {{{\cos }^2}{x \over 2} - {{\sin }^2}{x \over 2}} \right)} \over {2{{\cos }^2}{x \over 2} + 2\sin {x \over 2}\cos {x \over 2}}}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = \int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {\sin {x \over 2}\left( {\cos {x \over 2} - \sin {x \over 2}} \right)dx} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = {1 \over 2}\int\limits_0^{{\pi \over 2}} {(\sin x + \cos x - 1)dx} $$

$$ \Rightarrow I = {1 \over 2}[ - \cos x + \sin x - x]_0^{\pi /2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow I = {1 \over 2}\left[ {\left( { - \cos {\pi \over 2} + \sin {\pi \over 2} - {\pi \over 2}} \right) - ( - \cos 0 + \sin 0 - 0} \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow I = {1 \over 2}\left[ {0 + 1 - {\pi \over 2} + 1} \right] = 1 - {\pi \over 4}$$

questions.content: The root of the equation $$2(1 + i){x^2} - 4(2 - i)x - 5 - 3i = 0$$, where $$i = \sqrt { - 1} $$, which has greater modulus, is
questions.explanation:
The given equation is

$$2(1 + i){x^2} - 4(2 - i)x - 5 - 3i = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow x = {{4(2 - i) \pm \sqrt {16{{(2 - i)}^2} + 8(1 + i)(5 + 3i)} } \over {4(1 + i)}}$$

$$ = - {i \over {1 + i}}$$ or $${{4 - i} \over {1 + i}} = {{ - 1 - i} \over 2}$$ or, $${{3 - 5i} \over 2}$$

Now, $$\left| {{{ - 1 - i} \over 1}} \right| = \sqrt {{1 \over 4} + {1 \over 4}} = \sqrt {{1 \over 2}} $$

and $$\left| {{{3 - 5i} \over 2}} \right| = \sqrt {{9 \over 4} + {{25} \over 4}} = \sqrt {{{17} \over 2}} $$

Also, $$\sqrt {{{17} \over 2}} > \sqrt {{1 \over 2}} $$

Hence, required root is $${{3 - 5i} \over 2}$$.

So, sin$$\beta$$ should be > 0. [$$\because$$ $${\cos ^2}\beta \ge 0,\,1 - \cos \beta \ge 0$$]

$$ \Rightarrow \beta \in (0,\pi )$$.

For unique solution $$\left| {\matrix{ {1 + \alpha } & \beta & 1 \cr \alpha & {1 + \beta } & 1 \cr \alpha & \beta & 2 \cr } } \right| \ne 0$$

Apply R1 $$\to$$ R1 - R2 and R2 $$\to$$ R2 - R3, we get

$$\left| {\matrix{ 1 & { - 1} & 0 \cr 0 & 1 & { - 1} \cr \alpha & \beta & 2 \cr } } \right| \ne 0$$

Expanding along R1, we get

$$1(2 + \beta ) + 1(0 + \alpha ) \ne 0$$

$$ = \alpha + \beta + 2 \ne 0$$

Only option (c) satisfied above equation.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: A bird is sitting on the top of a vertical pole 20 m high and its elevation from a point O on the ground is 45$$^\circ$$. If flies off horizontally straight way from the point O. After one second, the elevation of the bird from O is reduced to 30$$^\circ$$, then the speed (in m/s) of the bird is
questions.explanation:
Let AB = h = height of vertical pole

OA = x = Horizontal distance from O to pole

In $$\Delta$$OAB

$$\tan 45^\circ = {{AB} \over {OA}} = 1 = {{20} \over x} \Rightarrow x = 20$$ m

In $$\Delta$$OPQ

$$\tan 30^\circ = {{PQ} \over {OP}} \Rightarrow {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }} = {{20} \over {x + y}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow x + y = 20\sqrt 3 $$

$$ \Rightarrow y = 20\sqrt 3 - x = 20\sqrt 3 - 20 = 20(\sqrt 3 - 1)$$

$$\therefore$$ Speed of bird is $$20(\sqrt 3 - 1)$$ m/s.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If one GM, g and two AM's p and q are inserted between two numbers a and b, then (2p $$-$$ q) (p $$-$$ 2q) is equal to
questions.explanation:
Since, $$g = \sqrt {ab} $$. Also, a, p, q and b are in AP.

So, common difference d is $${{b - a} \over 3}$$.

$$\therefore$$ $$p = a + d = a + {{b - a} \over 3} = {{2a + b} \over 3}$$

$$q = b - d = b - {{b - a} \over 3} = {{a + 2b} \over 3}$$

Now, $$(2p - q)(p - 2q)$$

$$ = {{(4a + 2b - a - 2b)} \over 3}\,.\,{{(2a + b - 2a - 4b)} \over 3}$$

$$ = - ab = - {g^2}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: When x100 is divided by x2 $$-$$ 3x + 2, the remainder is (2k + 1 $$-$$ 1)x $$-$$(2k $$-$$ 1), then k is
questions.explanation:
Let f(x) = x100

g(x) = x2 $$-$$ 3x + 2

q(x) = quotient

r(x) = remainder = (ax + b)

$$\therefore$$ f(x) = g(x) q(x) + r(x)

x100 = (x2 $$-$$ 3x + 2) q(x) + ax + b

Put x = 1 $$\to$$ 1 = a + b ..... (i)

Put x = 2 $$\Rightarrow$$ 2100 = 2a + b ..... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

a = 2100 $$-$$ 1, b = 2 $$-$$ 2100

Remainder = (2100 $$-$$ 1)x + (2 $$-$$ 2100)

= (299 + 1 $$-$$ 1)x $$-$$ (299 $$-$$ 1)

$$\therefore$$ k = 99

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The mean of five observation is 5 and their variance is 9.20. If three of the given five observation are 1, 3 and 8, then a ratio of other two observations is
questions.explanation:
Let two observations be x and y.

$$\therefore$$ Mean $$ = {{1 + 3 + 8 + x + y} \over 5} = {{12 + x + y} \over 5}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 5 = {{x + y + 12} \over {15}} \Rightarrow x + y = 13$$ ..... (i)

Now, variance $$ = {{\sum {x_i^2} } \over n} - {(\overline x )^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 9.20 = {{{1^2} + {3^2} + {8^2} + {x^2} + {y^2}} \over 5} - 25$$

$$ \Rightarrow 46 = 74 + {x^2} + {y^2} - 125$$

$$ \Rightarrow {x^2} + {y^2} = 97$$ ...... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$${(x + y)^2} - 2xy = 97$$

$$ \Rightarrow {(13)^2} - 2xy = 97$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2xy = 169 - 97 = 72$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ xy = 36

$$\therefore$$ x : y = 4 : 9

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: How many three digit number satisfy the property that the middle digit is arithmetic mean of the first and the last digit.
questions.explanation:
Let's denote the three digits of the number as $a $, $b$, and $ c $, and thus the number we're looking at is $100a + 10b + c$. According to the property described, the middle digit $b $ is the arithmetic mean of $a $ and $c$, which means:

$$ b = \frac{a+c}{2} $$

In order for $b$ to be an integer, $a + c$ must be an even number since the sum of two numbers divided by 2 can only result in an integer if the sum is even.

Since $a$, $b$, and $c$ are digits, they can only take values from 0 to 9, inclusive. However, for $a$, it cannot be 0 because we are looking for a three-digit number, which means $a$ must be from 1 to 9.

Let's consider all possible even $a + c$ sums:

$a = 1$ allows $c = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9$ (since $1 + c$ must be even and $c$ can be from 0 to 9).

$a = 2$ allows $c = 0, 2, 4, 6, 8$ (for the same reason).

$a = 3$ allows $c = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9$.

...

$a = 9$ allows $c = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9$.

So for each odd $a$, there are 5 possible values for $c$, and for each even $a$, there are also 5 possible values for $c$, totaling 5 choices for $c$ for each value of $a$.

Since $a$ can be from 1 to 9, there are, in total:

$$ 9 \times 5 = 45 $$

possible three-digit numbers where the middle digit is the arithmetic mean of the first and last digits. Therefore, the correct answer is:

Option B: 45

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$z = r{e^{i\theta }}$$, then arg(eiz) is
questions.explanation:
We have,

$$Z = r{e^{i\theta }}$$

$$Z = r(\cos \theta + i\sin \theta )$$

$${e^{iz}} = {e^{ir(\cos \theta + i\sin \theta )}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {e^{iz}} = {e^{ir\cos \theta + {i^2}r\sin \theta }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {e^{iz}} = {e^{ir\cos \theta - r\sin \theta }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {e^{iz}} = {e^{ - r\sin \theta }}\,.\,{e^{ir\cos \theta }}$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\arg ({e^{iz}}) = r\cos \theta $$

questions.content: The measurement of the distance from point A(1, 2) parallel to the line 3x $$-$$ y = 10 to the line x + y + 5 = 0 is
questions.explanation:
A line passing through (1, 2) and parallel to the line 3x $$-$$ y = 10 is

3(x $$-$$ 1) $$-$$ (y $$-$$ 2) = 0

$$\Rightarrow$$ 3x $$-$$ 3 $$-$$ y + 2 = 0 $$\Rightarrow$$ 3x $$-$$ y $$-$$ 1 = 0

The intersection point of line

x + y + 5 = 0 ..... (i)

and 3x $$-$$ y $$-$$ 1 = 0 ..... (ii)

are ($$-$$1, $$-$$4)

$$\therefore$$ Distance from the line x + y + 5 to the point (1, 2) measured parallel to the line 3x $$-$$ y = 10 is

$$\sqrt {{{( - 1 - 1)}^2} + {{( - 4 - 2)}^2}} $$

$$\sqrt {4 + 36} = \sqrt {40} = 2\sqrt {10} $$

questions.content: Let $$f(x) = {a_0} + {a_1}{x^2} + {a_2}{x^4} + {a_3}{x^6} + ... + {a_n}{x^{2n}}$$ be a polynomial in a real variable x with $$0 < {a_1} < {a_2} < {a_3} < .... < {a_n}$$, the function f(x) has

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: A line passing through P(3, 7, 1) and R(2, 5, 7) meet the plane 3x + 2y + 11z $$-$$ 9 = 0 at Q. Then PQ is equal to
questions.explanation:
We have P(3, 7, 1) and R(2, 5, 7)

DR's of PR = ($$-$$1, $$-$$2, 6)

Angle between line PQ and plane is

$$\sin \theta = {{( - 1)(3) + ( - 2) \times 2 + 6 \times 11} \over {\sqrt {1 + 4 + 36} \sqrt {9 + 4 + 121} }}$$

$$\sin \theta = {{59} \over {\sqrt {41} \sqrt {134} }}$$

$$PM = \left| {{{3(3) + 2(7) + 11( \times 1) - 9} \over {\sqrt {9 + 4 + 121} }}} \right|$$

$$ = \left| {{{9 + 14 + 11 - 9} \over {\sqrt {134} }}} \right| = {{25} \over {\sqrt {134} }}$$

$$\sin \theta = {{PM} \over {PQ}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow PQ = {{PM} \over {\sin \theta }} = {{25} \over {\sqrt {134} }} \times {{\sqrt {41} \times \sqrt {134} } \over {59}} = {{25\sqrt {41} } \over {59}}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$a = - \widehat i + \widehat j + \widehat k$$ and $$b = 2\widehat i + \widehat k$$, then find z component of a vector r, which is coplanar with a and b, r . b = 0 and r . a = 7.
questions.explanation:
We have,

Vector r is coplanar with vector a and b

$$\therefore$$ $$r = \lambda (b \times (a \times b))$$

$$ \Rightarrow r = \lambda ((b\,.\,b)a - (b\,.\,a)b)$$

$$ \Rightarrow r = \lambda (|b{|^2}a - (a\,.\,b)b)$$

$$ \Rightarrow r = \lambda [5a + b]$$ [$$\because$$ $$|b| = \sqrt {{2^2} + {1^2}} = \sqrt 5 $$]

and $$a\,.\,b = ( - \widehat i + \widehat j + \widehat k)\,.\,(2\widehat i + \widehat k) = - 1$$

Given, $$r\,.\,a = 7$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\lambda (5a + b)\,.\,a = 7$$

$$ \Rightarrow \lambda [5|a{|^2} + a\,.\,b] = 7$$

$$ \Rightarrow \lambda [15 - 1] = 7$$ [$$\because$$ $$|a{|^2} = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3$$]

$$ \Rightarrow \lambda = {1 \over 2}$$

$$\therefore$$ $$r = {1 \over 2}(5a + b)$$

$$r = {1 \over 2}( - 5\widehat i + 5\widehat j + 5\widehat k + 2\widehat i + \widehat k)$$

$$r = {{ - 3} \over 2}\widehat i + {5 \over 2}\widehat j + {6 \over 2}\widehat k$$

z component of $$r = {6 \over 2} = 3$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Given that x, y, and z are three consecutive positive integers and x $$-$$ z + 2 = 0, what is the value of $${1 \over 2}{\log _e}x + {1 \over 2}{\log _e}z + {1 \over {2xz + 1}} + {1 \over 3}{\left( {{1 \over {2xz + 1}}} \right)^3} + ...$$?
questions.explanation:
Since x, y, z are three consecutive integers

$$\therefore$$ 2y = x + z

$$\Rightarrow$$ (4y2) = (x + z)2

= (x $$-$$ z)2 + 4xz

= ($$-$$2)2 + 4xz [$$\because$$ x $$-$$ z = $$-$$2]

$$\Rightarrow$$ 4y2 = 4 + 4xz

$$\Rightarrow$$ y2 = 1 + xz

Now,

$${1 \over 2}{\log _e}x + {1 \over 2}{\log _e}z + {1 \over {2xz + 1}} + {1 \over 3}{\left( {{1 \over {2xz + 1}}} \right)^3} + ...$$

$$ = {1 \over 2}\left[ {{{\log }_e}(xz) + 2\left( {{1 \over {2zx + 1}} + {1 \over 3}\,.\,{1 \over {{{(2zx + 1)}^3}}} + ...} \right)} \right]$$

$$ = {1 \over 2}\left[ {{{\log }_e}(xz) + {{\log }_e}\left( {{{1 + {1 \over {2zx + 1}}} \over {1 - {1 \over {2zx + 1}}}}} \right)} \right]$$

$$ = {1 \over 2}\left[ {{{\log }_e}(xz) + {{\log }_e}\left( {{{1 + xz} \over {xz}}} \right)} \right]$$

$$ = {1 \over 2}[{\log _e}(1 + xz)] = {1 \over 2}[{\log _e}{(y)^2}] = {\log _e}(y)$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The solution of differential equation $$(x{y^5} + 2y)dx - xdy = 0$$, is
questions.explanation:
We have, $$(x{y^5} + 2y)dx = x\,dy$$

$$ \Rightarrow x{{dy} \over {dx}} - 2y = x{y^5}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{dy} \over {dx}} - {{2y} \over x} = {y^5}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {y^{ - 5}}{{dy} \over {dx}} - {{2{y^{ - 4}}} \over x} = 1$$ ..... (i)

Put, $${y^{ - 4}} = t$$

$$ \Rightarrow - 4{y^{ - 5}}{{dy} \over {dx}} = {{dt} \over {dx}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {y^{ - 5}}{{dy} \over {dx}} = {{ - 1} \over 4}{{dt} \over {dx}}$$ ..... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$ - {1 \over 4}{{dt} \over {dx}} - {{2t} \over x} = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{dt} \over {dx}} + {{8t} \over x} = - 4$$

Now, $$IF = {e^{\int {{8 \over x}dx} }} = {e^{8\log x}} = {x^8}$$

and the solution is

$$t\,.\,{x^8} = \int {( - 4){x^8}dx + C} $$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{x^8}} \over {{y^4}}} = - {{4\,.\,{x^9}} \over 9} + C$$

$$ \Rightarrow 9{x^8} + 4{x^9}\,.\,{y^4} = 9{y^4}C$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The solution set of $${{|x - 2|\, - 1} \over {|x - 2|\, - 2}} \le 0$$ is
questions.explanation:
Given, $${{|x - 2|\, - 1} \over {|x - 2|\, - 2}} \le 0$$

Let $$|x - 2|\, = k$$

Then, given equation,

$${{k - 1} \over {k - 2}} \le 0 \Rightarrow {{(k - 1)(k - 2)} \over {{{(k - 2)}^2}}} \le 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow (k - 1)(k - 2) \le 0 \Rightarrow 1 \le k \le 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow 1 \le |x - 2|\, \le 2$$

Case I When $$1 \le |x - 2|$$

$$ \Rightarrow |x - 2| \ge 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow x - 2 \ge 1$$ or $$x - 2 \le - 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow x \ge 3$$ and $$x \le 1$$ ..... (i)

Case II When $$|x - 2| \le 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow - 2 \le x - 2 \le 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow - 2 + 2 \le x \le 2 + 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow 0 \le x \le 4$$ ..... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), $$x \in [0,1] \cup [3,4]$$.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let $$f(x) = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + {x^2}} }}$$, $$\underbrace {fofofo.....of(x)}_{x\,times}$$ is
questions.explanation:
We have, $$f(x) = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + {x^2}} }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow f(f(x)) = {{f(x)} \over {\sqrt {1 + {{(f(x))}^2}} }} = {{{x \over {\sqrt {1 + {x^2}} }}} \over {\sqrt {1 + {{{x^2}} \over {1 + {x^2}}}} }} = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + 2{x^2}} }}$$

Similarly, $$f(f(f(x))) = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + 3{x^2}} }}$$

$$\underbrace {fofofo.....of(x)}_{x\,times} = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + n{x^2}} }} = {x \over {\sqrt {1 + \left( {\sum\limits_{r = 1}^n 1 } \right){x^2}} }}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.explanation:
We have,

$${\log _5}{{(a + b)} \over 3} = {{{{\log }_5}a + {{\log }_5}b} \over 2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2{\log _5}\left( {{{a + b} \over 3}} \right) = {\log _5}ab$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\log _5}{\left( {{{a + b} \over 3}} \right)^2} = {\log _5}ab$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{{(a + b)}^2}} \over 9} = ab$$

$$ \Rightarrow {(a + b)^2} = 9ab$$

$$ \Rightarrow {a^2} + {b^2} = 7ab$$

$$ \Rightarrow {a \over b} + {b \over a} = 7$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\left( {{a \over b} + {b \over a}} \right)^2} = 49$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{a^2}} \over {{b^2}}} + {{{b^2}} \over {{a^2}}} + 2 = 49$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{a^4} + {b^4}} \over {{a^2}{b^2}}} = 49 - 2 = 47$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The number of distinct solutions of the equation $${5 \over 4}{\cos ^2}2x + {\cos ^4}x + {\sin ^4}x + {\cos ^6}x = 2$$ in the interval [0, 2$$\pi$$] is
questions.explanation:
We have,

$${5 \over 4}{\cos ^2}2x + {\cos ^4}x + {\sin ^4}x + {\cos ^6}x + {\sin ^6}x = 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow {5 \over 4}{\cos ^2}2x + {({\cos ^2}x + {\sin ^2}x)^2} - 2{\sin ^2}x{\cos ^2}x + {({\cos ^2}x + {\sin ^2}x)^3} - 3{\sin ^2}x{\cos ^2}x({\sin ^2}x + {\cos ^2}x) = 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow {5 \over 4}{\cos ^2}2x + 1 - 2{\sin ^2}x{\cos ^2}x + 1 - 3{\sin ^2}x{\cos ^2}x = 2$$

$$ \Rightarrow {5 \over 4}{\cos ^2}2x - {1 \over 2}{\sin ^2}2x - {3 \over 4}{\sin ^2}2x = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {5 \over 4}({\cos ^2}2x - {\sin ^2}2x) = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow \cos 4x = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4x = 2n\pi \, \pm {\pi \over 2},n \in Z$$

$$ \Rightarrow x = (4n \pm 1){\pi \over 8},n \in Z$$

$$ \Rightarrow x = {\pi \over 8},{{3\pi } \over 8},{{5\pi } \over 8},{{7\pi } \over 8},{{9\pi } \over 8},{{11\pi } \over 8},{{13\pi } \over 8},{{15\pi } \over 8}$$

So, number of solution = 8

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If the tangent at a point $$\left( {4\cos \phi ,{{16} \over {\sqrt {11} }}\sin \phi } \right)$$ to the ellipse $$16{x^2} + 11{y^2} = 256$$ is also a tangent to $${x^2} + {y^2} - 2x = 15$$, then $$\phi$$ equsls
questions.explanation:
Given equation of ellipse

$$16{x^2} + 11{y^2} = 256 \Rightarrow {{{x^2}} \over {16}} + {{11{y^2}} \over {256}} = 1$$

Equation of tangent of ellipse at $$\left( {4\cos \phi ,{{16} \over {\sqrt {11} }}\sin \phi } \right)$$ is

$${{4x\cos \phi } \over {16}} + {{11 \times 16y} \over {256\sqrt {11} }}\sin \phi = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{x\cos \phi } \over 4} + {{\sqrt {11} } \over {16}}\sin \phi y = 1$$

is also a tangent of circle $${x^2} + {y^2} - 2x = 15$$

$$ \Rightarrow {(x - 1)^2} + {y^2} = 16$$

radius of circle = 4 and centre = (1, 0)

Now, $${{x\cos \phi } \over 4} + {{\sqrt {11} } \over {16}}\sin \phi y = 1$$ is tangent of circle.

$$\therefore$$ $$4 = \left| {{{{{\cos \phi } \over 4} - 1} \over {\sqrt {{{{{\cos }^2}\phi } \over {16}} + {{11} \over {256}}{{\sin }^2}\phi } }}} \right| \Rightarrow \phi = \pm {\pi \over 3}$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\phi = {\pi \over 3}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The distance of point of intersection of the tangents to the parabola x = 4y $$-$$ y2 drawn at the points where it is meet by Y-axis, from its focus is
questions.explanation:
Given equation of parabola is

x = 4y $$-$$ y2

$$\Rightarrow$$ y2 $$-$$ 4y + 4 = $$-$$ x + 4

$$\Rightarrow$$ (y $$-$$ 2)2 = $$-$$ (x $$-$$ 4)

a = $${{1} \over 4}$$

Focus = $$\left( {{{15} \over 4},2} \right)$$

Parabola cuts Y-axis of (0, 0) and (0, 4)

Now, equation of tangent at (0, 0) is

x = 4y ...... (i)

and equation of tangent at (0, 4) is

x + 4y = 16 .... (ii)

Solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

x = 8, y = 2

$$\therefore$$ Intersection point of tangent is P(8, 2).

Distance from point P to focus S

Distance = $$\sqrt {{{\left( {8 - {{15} \over 4}} \right)}^2} + {{(2 - 2)}^2}} $$

$$ = 8 - {{15} \over 4} = {{17} \over 4}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The value of the sum $$\sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {\sum\limits_{n = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^{n + k}}}}} } $$ is
questions.explanation:
We have, $${S_\infty } = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {\sum\limits_{n = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^{n + k}}}}} } $$

$${S_\infty } = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^k}}}\,.\,\sum\limits_{n = 1}^\infty {{1 \over {{2^n}}}} } $$

$${S_\infty } = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^k}}}\left( {{1 \over 2} + {1 \over {{2^2}}} + {1 \over {{2^3}}} + ....} \right)} $$

$${S_\infty } = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^k}}}\left[ {{1 \over 2}\left( {1 + {1 \over 2} + {1 \over {{2^2}}}...} \right)} \right]} $$

$${S_\infty } = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^k}}}\left( {{1 \over 2} \times {1 \over {1 - {1 \over 2}}}} \right) = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^\infty {{k \over {{2^k}}}} } $$

$${S_\infty } = {1 \over 2} + {2 \over {{2^2}}} + {3 \over {{2^3}}} + {4 \over {{2^4}}} + ...$$ ..... (i)

$${1 \over 2}{S_\infty } = {1 \over {{2^2}}} + {2 \over {{2^3}}} + {3 \over {{2^4}}} + ...$$ ...... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$${1 \over 2}{S_\infty } = {1 \over 2} + {1 \over {{2^2}}} + {1 \over {{2^3}}} + ...$$

$${1 \over 2}{S_\infty } = {1 \over 2}\left( {{1 \over {1 - {1 \over 2}}}} \right)$$

$${1 \over 2}{S_\infty } = 1$$

$${S_\infty } = 2$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: A curve passes through (2, 0) and the slope of the tangent at P(x, y) is equal to $${{{{(x + 1)}^2} + y - 3} \over {x + 1}}$$ then the equation of the curve is
questions.explanation:
We have,

Slope of tangent of the curve is $${{{{(x + 1)}^2} + y - 3} \over {x + 1}}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{dy} \over {dx}} = {{{{(x + 1)}^2} + y - 3} \over {x + 1}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{dy} \over {dx}} = {{{{(x + 1)}^2} - 3} \over {x + 1}} + {y \over {x + 1}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{dy} \over {dx}} - {y \over {x + 1}} = {{{{(x + 1)}^2} - 3} \over {x + 1}}$$

This is a form of linear differential equations

$$\therefore$$ $$IF = {e^{\int {{{ - 1} \over {x + 1}}dx} }} = {e^{\log {1 \over {1 + x}}}} = {1 \over {1 + x}}$$

Solution of given differential equation is

$${y \over {x + 1}} = \int {{{{{(x + 1)}^2} - 3} \over {{{(x + 1)}^2}}}dx} $$

$${y \over {x + 1}} = \int {\left( {1 - {3 \over {{{(x + 1)}^2}}}} \right)dx} $$

$${y \over {x + 1}} = x + {3 \over {x + 1}} + c$$

$$\because$$ Curve passes through (2, 0)

$$\therefore$$ $$0 = 2 + {3 \over 3} + c$$

$$ \Rightarrow c = - 3$$

Hence, equation of curve is

$${y \over {x + 1}} = x + {3 \over {x + 1}} - 3$$

$$y = {x^2} + x + 3 - 3x - 3$$

$$y = {x^2} - 2x$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Consider matrix $$A = \left[ {\matrix{ 2 & 1 \cr 1 & 2 \cr } } \right]$$, if $${A^{ - 1}} = \alpha I + \beta A$$, where $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$ $$ \notin $$ R, then ($$\alpha$$ + $$\beta$$) is equal to (where A$$-$$1 denotes the inverse of matrix A)
questions.explanation:
We have,

$$A = \left[ {\matrix{ 2 & 1 \cr 1 & 2 \cr } } \right]$$

We know that, $$\left| {A \to \lambda I} \right| = 0$$

$$\left| {\left[ {\matrix{ 2 & 1 \cr 1 & 2 \cr } } \right] - \left[ {\matrix{ \lambda & 0 \cr 0 & \lambda \cr } } \right]} \right| = 0$$

$$ = \left| {\matrix{ {2 - \lambda } & 1 \cr 1 & {2 - \lambda } \cr } } \right| = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {(2 - \lambda )^2} - 1 = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4 - 4\lambda + {\lambda ^2} - 1 = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\lambda ^2} - 4\lambda + 3 = 0$$

$$\therefore$$ $${A^2} - 4A + 3I = 0$$

Multiply by A$$-$$1, we get

$$A - 4I + 3{A^{ - 1}} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {A^{ - 1}} = {{ - 1} \over 3}A + {4 \over 3}I$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\alpha = - {1 \over 3}$$ and $$\beta = {4 \over 3}$$

$$\alpha + \beta = - {1 \over 3} + {4 \over 3} = {3 \over 3} = 1$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Three solenoid coils of same dimensions, same number of turns and same number of layers of windings are taken. Coil 1 has inductance L1 wounded by Mn wire of resistance 6 $$\Omega$$m$$-$$1, coil 2 with inductance L2 wounded by similar wire but in reverse direction in each layer. Coil 3 with inductance L3 wounded by a superconducting wire. The relation between their self inductances will be
questions.explanation:
As coil 2 with inductance L2 has been wounded by a similar wire as coil 1 but the direction of windings is reversed in each layer, so flux through L2 will be zero.

As, L2 $$\propto$$ $$\phi$$ $$\Rightarrow$$ L2 = 0

Also, since the dimensions, number of turns and number of layers of windings are equal in coil 1 and 3.

So, L1 = L3

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Three capacitors C1, C2 and C3 are connected as shown in the figure below. If capacitor C3 breaks down electrically, the change in total charge on the combination of capacitors is
questions.explanation:
Since capacitors C1 and C2 are parallel, so their equivalent capacitance will be (C1 + C2). Now, (C1 + C2) and C3 are in series, so the net equivalent capacitance of circuit will be,

$${1 \over C} = {1 \over {{C_3}}} + {1 \over {{C_1} + {C_2}}} = {{{C_1} + {C_2} + {C_3}} \over {({C_1} + {C_2}){C_3}}}$$

or, $$C = {{({C_1} + {C_2}){C_3}} \over {{C_1} + {C_2} + {C_3}}}$$

Since V is the voltage of the battery, so charge on this system,

$$q = CV \Rightarrow q = {{({C_1} + {C_2}){C_3}V} \over {({C_1} + {C_2} + {C_3})}}$$

If the capacitance C3 breaks down, then total equivalent capacitance will become

$$C' = {C_1} + {C_2}$$

$$\therefore$$ New charge stored,

$$q' = C'V$$

$$ \Rightarrow q' = ({C_1} + {C_2})V$$

Now, change in total charge,

$$\Delta q = q' - q$$ [$$\because$$ $$q' > q$$]

$$ = ({C_1} + {C_2})V - {{({C_1} + {C_2}){C_3}V} \over {{C_1} + {C_2} + {C_2}}}$$

or, $$\Delta q = ({C_1} + {C_2})V\left[ {1 - \left( {{{{C_3}} \over {{C_1} + {C_2} + {C_3}}}} \right)} \right]$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A black body radiates energy at the rate E Wm$$-$$2 at high temperature TK. When the temperature is reduced to $$\left( {{T \over 4}} \right)$$ K, the new radiant energy is
questions.explanation:
Let E' be the new radiant energy.

According to Stefan's law,

E $$\propto$$ T4

$$\Rightarrow$$ $${{{E_2}} \over {{E_1}}} = {\left( {{{{T_2}} \over {{T_1}}}} \right)^4}$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ $${{E'} \over E} = {\left\{ {{{(T/4)} \over T}} \right\}^4} = {\left( {{1 \over 4}} \right)^4}$$

or, $$E' = {E \over {256}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The length of the rectangle is l = 15.2 cm and breadth is b = 2.9 cm and the minimum possible measurement by scale = 0.1 cm. Then, the area of the rectangle is (Taking significant figures into consideration)
questions.explanation:
Area of rectangle, A = lb = 15.2 $$\times$$ 2.9 = 44.08 cm2

Minimum possible measurement of scale = 0.1 cm

As we know, the product should have significant figures that are present in the measurement with least number of significant figures which is 2 in this case. So, area measured by scale = 44 cm2.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In an adiabatic process, where pressure is decreased by $${3 \over 4}$$%, if $${{{C_p}} \over {{C_v}}} = {4 \over 3}$$, then the volume increases by
questions.explanation:
In adiabatic process,

pV$$\gamma$$ = K

where, K is a constant.

Given that, $$\gamma = {4 \over 3} \Rightarrow p{V^{4/3}} = K$$

Taking logarithm on both sides, we get

$$\log p + {4 \over 3}\log V = \log K$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{\Delta p} \over p} + {4 \over 3}{{\Delta V} \over V} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{\Delta V} \over V} = - {3 \over 4}{{\Delta p} \over p}$$

Now, % change in volume,

$${{\Delta V} \over V} \times 100 = - {3 \over 4}\left( {{{\Delta p} \over p} \times 100} \right)$$

It is given that, pressure decreases by $${3 \over 4}$$%,

i.e. $${{\Delta p} \over p} \times 100 = - {3 \over 4}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{\Delta V} \over V} \times 100 = - {3 \over 4} \times \left( { - {3 \over 4}} \right) = {9 \over {16}}$$%

Hence, the volume increases by $${9 \over {16}}$$%.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
The vibrations of a string of length 60 cm fixed at both ends are represented by the equation

$$y = 4\sin \left( {{{\pi x} \over {15}}} \right)\cos (96\pi t)$$

where x and y are in cm and t is in second. Calculate the velocity of the particle at x = 7.5 cm at t = 0.25 s.
questions.explanation:
The given equation is

$$y = 4\sin \left( {{{\pi x} \over {15}}} \right)\cos (96\pi t)$$ ...... (i)

This equation is similar to the displacement equation of a travelling wave, $$y = A\sin (\omega t - kx)$$

On comparing these two equations, we get

$$\omega = 2\pi v = 96\pi $$

or, $$\nu = {{96\pi } \over {2\pi }} = 48$$ Hz

Now, the velocity of the string at a point x at time t is obtained by differentiating Eq. (i) w.r.t.

$$\therefore$$ $$v = {{dy} \over {dt}} = - (4 \times 9\pi ) \times \sin \left( {{{\pi x} \over {15}}} \right)\sin (96\pi t)$$

At x = 7.5 cm = 7.5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$2 m and t = 0.25 s,

$$v = - 384\pi \sin \left( {\pi \times {{7.5 \times {{10}^{ - 2}}} \over {15}}} \right)\sin \left( {96\pi \times {{25} \over {100}}} \right)$$

$$ = - 384\pi \sin \left( {{\pi \over {200}}} \right)\sin (24\pi )$$

$$ = 0$$ ($$\because$$ $$\sin 24\pi = 0$$)

Hence, the velocity of the particle is zero.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A charge +q is placed at the origin O of XY-axes as shown in the figure. The work done in taking a charge Q from A to B along the straight line AB is
questions.explanation:
Potential at point A,

$${V_A} = {1 \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}}.{q \over a}$$

Potential at point B,

$${V_B} = {1 \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}}.{q \over b}$$

Work done in taking a charge Q from A to B,

$$W = Q({V_B} - {V_A}) = {{Qq} \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}}\left[ {{1 \over b} - {1 \over a}} \right] = {{Qq} \over {4\pi {\varepsilon _0}}}\left[ {{{a - b} \over {ab}}} \right]$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Identify the hydrogen-like element whose spectral lines are four times shorter in wavelength compared to those of atomic hydrogen.
questions.explanation:
For hydrogen-like atom,

$${1 \over {\lambda '}} = R{Z^2}\left( {{1 \over {n_1^2}} - {1 \over {n_2^2}}} \right)$$ ..... (i)

Similarly, for hydrogen atom,

$${1 \over \lambda } = R\left( {{1 \over {n_1^2}} - {1 \over {n_2^2}}} \right)$$ ....... (i)

For the element to have hydrogen-like spectrum, the ratio of the wavelengths for transition of electron between any two levels n1 and n2 should be constant.

Dividing eq. (ii) by eq. (i), we get

$${{\lambda '} \over \lambda } = {{R\left( {{1 \over {n_1^2}} - {1 \over {n_2^2}}} \right)} \over {R{Z^2}\left( {{1 \over {n_1^2}} - {1 \over {n_2^2}}} \right)}}$$ or $${{\lambda '} \over \lambda } = {1 \over {{Z^2}}}$$

It is given that wavelength of the hydrogen atom is four times the wavelength of the hydrogen-like atom, i.e.

$$\lambda = 4\lambda '$$

Hence, $$Z = 2$$

Now, the element with atomic number 2 is helium.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two small conducting spheres of equal radius have charges +20 $$\mu$$ C and $$-$$40 $$\mu$$C respectively and placed at a distance R from each other experience for F1. If they are brought in contact and separated to the same distance, they experience force F2. The ratio of F1 to F2 is
questions.explanation:
Given, two small conducting spheres of equal radius (R).

Charge on first sphere, q1 = +20 $$\mu$$C

Charge on second sphere, q2 = $$-$$40 $$\mu$$C

$$\therefore$$ $${F_1} = {{k( + 20)( - 40)} \over {{R^2}}} = {{ - k(800)} \over {{R^2}}}$$ ..... (i)

The spheres have equal radii, so their capacities will be same. Now, if they are brought in contact, then the net charge,

qnet = (+20 $$-$$40) $$\mu$$C = $$-$$20 $$\mu$$C

So, each sphere will have charge, $$q = {{{q_{net}}} \over 2} = - 10$$ $$\mu$$C

Now, $${F_2} = {{k(q)(q)} \over {{R^2}}} = {{k( - 10)( - 10)} \over {{R^2}}} = {{k(100)} \over {{R^2}}}$$ ..... (ii)

Ratio, $${{{F_1}} \over {{F_2}}} = - {{800} \over {100}} = - 8:1$$

Thus, ratio of F1 to F2 = $$-$$8 : 1

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A Carnot engine has the same efficiency between 600 K to 300 K and 1600 K to x K, then the value of x is
questions.explanation:
Efficiency of Carnot engine is given by

$$\eta = 1 - {{{T_2}} \over {{T_1}}}$$

Given, T1 = 600 K

T2 = 300 K

T'1 = 1600 K and T'2 = x K

Carnot engine has same efficiency between 600 K to 300 K and 1600 K to x K, so

$$\left( {1 - {{{T_2}} \over {{T_1}}}} \right) = \left( {1 - {{T{'_2}} \over {T{'_1}}}} \right)$$

Substituting all the given values in above equation, we get

$$1 - {{300} \over {600}} = 1 - {x \over {1600}}$$

$$1 - {1 \over 2} = 1 - {x \over {1600}}$$

$${x \over {1600}} = 1 - {1 \over 2} = {1 \over 2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow x = {{1600} \over 2} = 800$$ K

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A ball of mass 0.5 kg is thrown up with initial speed 16 ms$$-$$1 and reaches maximum height of 9 m. How much energy is dissipated by air drag acting on the ball during the ascent?
questions.explanation:
Given, initial speed of ball, v = 16 ms$$-$$1

Maximum height, h = 9 m

Mass of ball, m = 0.5 kg

Energy supplied to ball while throwing up,

$${E_1} = {1 \over 2}m{v^2} = {1 \over 2} \times 0.5 \times 16 \times 16 = 64$$ J

Energy stored when ball reaches the maximum height,

E2 = mgh = 0.5 $$\times$$ 9.8 $$\times$$ 9 = 44.1 J

Energy dissipated by air drag acting on the ball during the ascent,

E = E1 = E2 = 64 $$-$$ 44.1 = 19.9 J

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the circuit shown, if the 10 $$\Omega$$ resistor is replaced by a resistor of 15 $$\Omega$$, then what is the amount of current drawn from the battery?
questions.explanation:
From the following circuit diagram, $${{{R_1}} \over {{R_3}}} = {{{R_2}} \over {{R_4}}}$$, so the given Wheatstone bridge is balanced.

Hence, there is no current in the wire of 10 $$\Omega$$ resistance.

As,

Now, if the 10 $$\Omega$$ wire is replaced with 15 $$\Omega$$ wire, the bridge still remains balanced. Hence, current drawn from battery will be 10A.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A time dependent force F = (8t) acts on a particle of mass 2 kg. If the particle starts from rest, the work done by the force during the first 1s will be
questions.explanation:
Given, force, F = (8t) N, Mass, m = 2 kg

From Newton's second law,

Force = Rate of change of momentum

$$F = {{dp} \over {dt}}$$

i.e. dp = Fdt

$$\therefore$$, $$p = \int {dp = \int_0^1 {F\,.\,dt = \int_0^1 {8t\,.\,dt} } } $$

$$ = 8\left[ {{{{t^2}} \over 2}} \right]_0^1 = 8\left( {{1 \over 2} - 0} \right)$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ p = 4 kg ms$$-$$1

Change in kinetic energy, $$\Delta K = {{{p^2}} \over {2m}} = {{{{(4)}^2}} \over {2 \times 2}} = 4$$ J

From work-energy theorem,

Work done = Change in kinetic energy

So, work done by the force during the first 1s,

W = $$\Delta$$K = 4J

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If L, R, C and V represent inductance, resistance, capacitance and potential difference respectively, then dimensions of $${L \over {RCV}}$$ are the same as those of
questions.explanation:
As, RC is the time constant, so it has the dimension of time and V has the dimensions of $$L{{dl} \over {dt}}$$.

$$\therefore$$ Dimensions of $${L \over {RCV}},\left[ {{L \over {RCV}}} \right] = {{[L]} \over {[RC][V]}}$$

$${{[L]} \over {[T][L]\left[ {{A \over T}} \right]}} = {{[L][T]} \over {[T][L][A]}} = {1 \over {[A]}}$$

So, $$\left( {{L \over {RCV}}} \right)$$ has the dimensions $$[{A^{ - 1}}]$$, i.e. same as the dimensions of $${1 \over {current}}$$.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
The magnetic field of a beam emerging from a fitter facing a flood light is given by

B = 10 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$8 sin(1 $$\times$$ 107z $$-$$ 3.6 $$\times$$ 1015t)T. The average intensity of the beam is
questions.explanation:
Given, magnetic field,

B = 10 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$8 sim(1 $$\times$$ 107z $$-$$ 3.6 $$\times$$ 1015t) T ......... (i)

Standard equation of magnetic field,

B = B0 sin(kz $$-$$ $$\omega$$t) ....... (ii)

On comparing Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

B0 = 10 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$8 T

The average intensity of the beam,

$${I_{av}} = {{B_0^2} \over {2{\mu _0}}} = {1 \over 2} \times {{{{(10 \times {{10}^{ - 8}})}^2} \times 3 \times {{10}^8}} \over {4\pi \times {{10}^{ - 7}}}}$$ [$$\because$$ $$c = 3 \times {10^8}$$ ms$$-$$1]

= 1.19 W/m2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Based on the provided velocity-time graph for an objects straight-line movement, determine the total distance covered and the average speed between t = 0 and t = 20 seconds.
questions.explanation:
Distance = area under speed-time graph as given in question.

$$\therefore$$ Distance travelled in 20s = area of $$\Delta$$OAB + area of $$\Delta$$BCD

$$ = {1 \over 2} \times 6 \times 10 + {1 \over 2} \times 6 \times 10 = 60$$ m

Displacement in 20 s = area of $$\Delta$$OAB $$-$$ area of $$\Delta$$BCD $$ = {1 \over 2} \times 6 \times 10 - {1 \over 2} \times 6 \times 10 = 30 - 30 = 0$$

Hence, average velocity $$ = {{displacement} \over {time}} = {0 \over t} = 0$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A thin equi-convex lens is made of glass of refractive index 1.5 and its focal length is 0.2 m. If it acts as a concave lens of focal length 0.5 cm when dipped in a liquid, the refractive index of the liquid is
questions.explanation:
The focal length of a convex lens of refractive index $$\mu$$g in air,

$${1 \over {{f_{air}}}} = ({\mu _g} - 1)\left( {{1 \over {{R_1}}} - {1 \over {{R_2}}}} \right)$$ ...... (i)

where, R1, R2 = radii of curvatures of its first and second surface.

When the lens is immersed in a liquid of refractive index $$\mu$$I, then refractive index of material of lens (glass) w.r.t. liquid is,

$${}_I{\mu _g} = {{{\mu _g}} \over {{\mu _I}}}$$ ..... (ii)

Now, focal length of lens in liquid

$${1 \over {f'}} = ({}_I{\mu _g} - 1)\left( {{1 \over {{R_1}}} - {1 \over {{R_2}}}} \right)$$ ...... (iii)

Dividing Eq. (i) by Eq. (iii), we get

$${{f'} \over {{f_{air}}}} = {{{\mu _g} - 1} \over {({}_I{\mu _g} - 1)}} = {{{\mu _g} - 1} \over {\left( {{{{\mu _g}} \over {{\mu _I}}} - 1} \right)}}$$

Given, f' = 0.5 m, fair = 0.2 m, $$\mu$$g = 1.5

Substituting all these values in above equation, we get

$$ - {{0.5} \over {0.2}} = {{1.5 - 1} \over {\left( {{{1.5} \over {{\mu _1}}} - 1} \right)}} = {{0.5} \over {\left( {{{1.5} \over {{\mu _1}}} - 1} \right)}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{1.5} \over {{\mu _I}}} - 1 = - 0.2 \Rightarrow {{1.5} \over {{\mu _I}}} - 1 - 0.2 = 0.8$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\mu _I} = {{15} \over 8}$$

$$\therefore$$ Refractive index of liquid $$ = {{15} \over 8}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A moving coil galvanometer has a resistance of 60 $$\Omega$$ and it indicates full deflection on passing a current of 4.5 mA. A voltmeter is made using this galvanometer and a 4.5 k$$\Omega$$ resistance. The maximum voltage, that can be measured using this voltmeter, will be close to
questions.explanation:
Given, resistance of galvanometer, Rg = 60$$\Omega$$

Current, Ig = 4.5 mA = 4.5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 A

Resistance used in converting a galvanometer into voltmeter, R = 4.5 k$$\Omega$$ = 4.5 $$\times$$ 103 $$\Omega$$

To make the voltmeter, the galvanometer and the high resistance (R) have to be connected in series combination as shown below.

Image

$$\therefore$$ Maximum current in galvanometer is

$${I_g} = {E \over {R + {R_g}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow E = {I_g}(R + {R_g})$$

$$ = 4.5 \times {10^{ - 3}} \times (4.5 \times {10^3} + 60)$$

$$ = 20.5$$ V

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The combination of the gates shown in following figure yields
questions.explanation:
The given combination of gates is shown below

The output of this combination can be determined by Boolean algebra.

$$\therefore$$ Output, $$X = \overline {\overline A \,.\,\overline B } = \overline{\overline A} + \overline{\overline B} $$ [Using De Morgan's theorem]

$$ \Rightarrow X = A + B$$

This is the output of OR gate. Hence, the given combination of gates yield OR gate.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A vessel contains one mole of O2 gas (molar mass 32) at a temperature T. The pressure of the gas is p. An identical vessel containing one mole of He gas (molar mass 4) at a temperature 2T has a pressure of
questions.explanation:
From gas equation,

$$pV = nRT \Rightarrow p = {{nRT} \over V}$$

Pressure of one mole of O2 gas,

$${(p)_{{O_2}}} = {{1 \times RT} \over V}$$ ..... (i)

Pressure of one mole of He gas,

$${(p)_{He}} = {{1 \times R(2T)} \over V}$$ ...... (ii)

Dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

$$\therefore$$ $${{{{(p)}_{He}}} \over {{{(p)}_{{O_2}}}}} = 2 \Rightarrow {(p)_{He}} = 2{(p)_{{O_2}}} = 2p$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The acceleration of a particle in m/s2 is given by a = (3t2 $$-$$ 2t + 1), where t is in second. If the particle starts with a velocity v = 1 m/s at t = 1s, then velocity of the particle at the end of 4s is
questions.explanation:
Acceleration, $$a = {{dv} \over {dt}} \Rightarrow dv = adt$$

Integrating both sides, $$\int {dv = \int {adt} } $$

Given, $$a = (3{t^2} - 2t + 1)$$ ms$$-$$2

Substituting this value in above equation, we get

$$v = \int {(3{t^2} - 2t + 1)dt} $$

$$ \Rightarrow v = {t^3} - {t^2} + t + C$$ ...... (i)

At t = 1s, v = 1 m/s

Substituting these values in Eq. (i), we get

$$\because$$ $$1 = 1 - 1 + 1 + C \Rightarrow C = 0$$

Substituting this value of C in Eq. (i), we get

$$ \Rightarrow v = {t^3} - {t^2} + t$$

when t = 4s, $$v = {(4)^2} - {(4)^2} + 4 = 52$$ m/s

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The figure shows graphs of pressure (p) versus density (d) for an ideal gas at two temperatures T1 and T2, then
questions.explanation:
From Ideal gas equation,

$$pV = nnT = {{mRT} \over M}$$

$$n = {{Molar\,mass\,(m)} \over {Molecular\,weight\,(M)}}$$

Here, n = number of moles, R = Gas constant, V = volume

$$ \Rightarrow {{pV} \over m} = {{RT} \over M}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {p \over {(m/V)}} = {{RT} \over M}$$

$${p \over d} = {{RT} \over m}$$ [$$\because$$ $${m \over v} = d$$]

$$ \Rightarrow {p \over d} \propto T$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ Slope of p versus d graph $$\propto$$ T

Since, slope is less for the gas at temperature T1.

Therefore, T1 < T2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two spheres of the same material and same radii r are touching each other. The gravitational force between the spheres is proportional to
questions.explanation:
The two spheres are touching each other as shown below.

Let m be the mass of each sphere.

Gravitational force between the spheres,

$$F = G{{m.m} \over {{{(2r)}^2}}} = G.{{{m^2}} \over {4{r^2}}}$$

$$ = G.{{{{\left[ {{4 \over 3}\pi {r^3}.\rho } \right]}^2}} \over {4{r^2}}}$$ [Mass = volume $$\times$$ density]

$$ = {{4G{\pi ^2}{r^6}{\rho ^2}} \over {3 \times 4{r^2}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow F = \left( {{{4G{\pi ^2}{\rho ^2}} \over 3}} \right){r^4} \Rightarrow F \propto {r^4}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A spherical lens of power $$-$$4D is placed at a distance of 15 cm from another spherical lens of power 5 D. A beam of parallel light falls on the first spherical lens. The final image formed is

options.content: real and at a distance of 40 cm from the lens of power 5 D
real and at a distance of 10 cm from the lens of power $$-$$4 D
virtual and at a distance of 40 cm from the lens of power $$-$$5 D

questions.explanation:
Power of first spherical lens, P1 = $$-$$4 D

The power of this lens is negative, hence it is diverging lens.

Focal length of first spherical lens,

$${f_1} = {1 \over {{P_1}}} = {1 \over {( - 4D)}} = - 0.25$$ m = $$-$$25 cm

Power of second spherical lens, P2 = 5 D

Power of this lens is positive, hence it is converging lens.

Focal length of second spherical lens,

$${f_2} = {1 \over {{P_2}}} = {1 \over {5D}} = 0.2$$ m = 20 cm

The given situation is shown in the following figure.

Now, the image I1 will be considered as object for converging lens.

For converging lens, distance of object,

u = $$-$$(25 + 15) = $$-$$40 cm and f2 = 20 cm

$$\therefore$$ Using lens formula,

$${1 \over {{f_2}}} = {1 \over v} - {1 \over u} \Rightarrow {1 \over {20}} - {1 \over v} - {1 \over { - 40}}$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ v = 40 cm

Since v is positive, so image formed will be real and will be formed at a distance of 40 cm from the lens of power 5 D (converging lens).

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The wheel of a car, accelerated uniformly from rest, rotates through 5 radians during the first second. The angle (in radians) rotated during the next second is
questions.explanation:
From 2nd equation of rotational motion,

$$\theta = {\omega _0}t + {1 \over 2}\alpha {t^2}$$

Given, $$\theta$$ = 5 rad, t = 1s, $$\omega$$0 = 0

Substituting all these values in above equation, we get

$$5 = 0 + {1 \over 2}\alpha {(1)^2} \Rightarrow \alpha = 0$$ rad/s2

The angle rotated by wheel of car during first two seconds,

$${\theta _2} = 0 + {1 \over 2} + \alpha {t^2} = {1 \over 2} \times 10 \times {2^2} = 20$$ radians

Hence, angle rotated during the 2nd second

= $$\theta$$2 = 0

= 2 $$-$$ 5 = 15 radians

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Lights of two different frequencies whose photons have energies 1.5 eV and 2.5 eV respectively illuminate a metallic surface whose work function is 0.5 eV successively. Ratio of maximum speeds of emitted electrons will be
questions.explanation:
Kinetic energy in photoelectric effect can be given as

KE = W $$-$$ W0 [W $$\to$$ incident energy, W0 $$\to$$ work function]

Given, (KE)1 = 1.5 $$-$$ 0.5 = 1 eV

(KE)2 = 2.5 $$-$$ 0.5 = 1.5 eV

$$\because$$ $${{{{(KE)}_1}} \over {{{(KE)}_2}}} = {1 \over {1.5}} = {2 \over 3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{1 \over 2}mv_1^2} \over {{1 \over 2}mv_2^2}} = {2 \over 3} \Rightarrow {{{v_1}} \over {{v_2}}} = \sqrt {{2 \over 3}} $$

$$\therefore$$ $${v_1}:{v_2} = \sqrt 2 :\sqrt 3 $$

So, the ratio of maximum speeds of emitted electrons is $$\sqrt 2 :\sqrt 3 $$.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When a body is dropped from a height h, then it hits the ground with a momentum p. If the same body is dropped from a height which is three times more than previous height, the percentage change in momentum when it hits the ground is
questions.explanation:
Initial momentum, Pi = mv

$${P_i} = m\sqrt {2gh} $$ [$$\because$$ $$v\sqrt {2gh} $$]

New height of body, $${h_1} = h + 3h = 4h$$

Now, final momentum,

$${P_f} = m\sqrt {2g\,.\,{h_1}} $$

$$ = m\sqrt {2g(4h)} $$

$$ = m\,.\,2\sqrt {2gh} = 2{P_i}$$

$$\therefore$$ % change in momentum = $${{{P_f} - {P_i}} \over {{P_i}}} \times 100$$

$$ = {{2{P_i} - {P_i}} \over {{P_i}}} \times 100$$

$$ = 100\% $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The reading of the ammeter for a germanium diode in the given circuit is
questions.explanation:
In this case, the diode is forward biased. Potential drop in a germanium diode in forward bias is around 0.3V.

Hence, current through the given circuit,

$$I = {{{V_{net}}} \over {{R_{eq}}}} = {{5 - 0.3} \over {2 + 3}} = {{4.7} \over 5}$$

I = 0.94A

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The decay constants of two radioactive substances X and Y are 4$$\lambda$$ and $$\lambda$$ respectively. At t = 0, a sample has the same number of two nuclei. The time taken for the ratio of number of nuclei to become $${1 \over {{e^3}}}$$ will be
questions.explanation:
Number of active nuclei after time t in a sample of radioactive substance is given by

N = N0e$$-$$$$\lambda$$ t

where, N0 = initial number of nuclei at t = 0 and $$\lambda$$ = decay constant.

Here, at t = 0, number of nuclei in sample X and Y are equal,

i.e., (N0)X = (N0)Y = N0

Also, $$\lambda$$X = 4$$\lambda$$ and $$\lambda$$Y = $$\lambda$$

So, after time t, number of active nuclei in X and Y are

$${N_X} = {N_0}{e^{ - 4\lambda t}}$$ and $${N_Y} = {N_0}{e^{ - 2\lambda t}}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${{{N_X}} \over {{N_Y}}} = {e^{ - 2\lambda t}}$$

$${1 \over {{e^3}}} = {1 \over {{e^{2\lambda t}}}}$$ [Given, $${{{N_X}} \over {{N_Y}}} = {1 \over {{e^3}}}$$]

$$ \Rightarrow 2\lambda t = 3 \Rightarrow t = {3 \over {2\lambda }}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: What is the magnitude of the force experienced per unit length by a thin wire that carries a current of I = 10 A and is formed into a semi-circle with a radius of R = 20$$\pi$$ cm at a point O?
questions.explanation:
Given, current in the wire, I = 10A

Radius of the wire, R = 20$$\pi$$ cm = 20$$\pi$$ $$\times$$ 10$$-$$2 m

Magnetic field produced by semi-circular current carrying thin wire at centre O,

$$B = {{{\mu _0}I} \over {4R}}$$

Substituting all the given values in above equation, we get

$$B = {{4\pi \times {{10}^{ - 7}} \times 10} \over {4 \times 20\pi \times {{10}^{ - 2}}}}$$

B = 5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$6 T

Now, magnitude of force per unit length,

F = IB = 10 $$\times$$ 5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$6

= 50 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$6 N/m

= 50 $$\mu$$N/m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A long cylindrical iron core of cross-sectional area 5 cm2 is inserted into a long solenoid having 4000 turns/meter and carrying a current 5 A. The magnetic field inside the core is $$\pi$$ T. Find the pole strength developed.
questions.explanation:
Given, area A = 5 cm2 = 5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$4 m2

Number of turns per unit length, n = 4000 turns/m

Magnetic field, B = $$\pi$$T

Current, i = 5A

Now, magnetic intensity, H = ni = 4000 $$\times$$ 5 = 2 $$\times$$ 104 Am$$-$$1

As, B = $$\mu$$0 (H + I) [I = intensity of magnetisation]

Substituting all the values in above equation, we get

$$\pi = 4\pi \times {10^{ - 7}}((2 \times {10^4}) + I)$$

$${1 \over 4} \times {10^7} = (2 \times {10^4}) + I$$

$$250 \times {10^4} = 2 \times {10^4} + I$$

$$I = 250 \times {10^4} - 2 \times {10^4}$$

$$ \Rightarrow I = 248 \times {10^4}$$ A/m

Now, pole strength, $$m = I \times A = 248 \times {10^4} \times 5 \times {10^{ - 4}}$$

= 1240 A-m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A plane requires for take off a speed of 72 kmh$$-$$1, the run on the ground being 50 m. The mass of the plane is 10000 kg and the coefficient of friction between the plane and the ground is 0.2. Assume that the plane accelerates uniformly during take off. The minimum force required by the engine of the plane for take off is
questions.explanation:
Given, mass of plane, M = 10000 kg

Coefficient of friction, $$\mu$$ = 0.2

Distance, s = 50 m

Initial speed, u = 0

Final speed, v = 72 kmh$$-$$1 = 20 ms$$-$$1

Let a be the acceleration of the plane.

From third equation of motion,

v2 $$-$$ u2 = 2as

(20)2 $$-$$ (0)2 = 2 $$\times$$ a $$\times$$ 50

$$\therefore$$ $$a = {{20 \times 20} \over {100}} = 4$$ ms$$-$$2

Force required to provide necessary acceleration to the plane,

F1 = ma = 10000 $$\times$$ 4 = 4 $$\times$$ 104 N

Force required to overcome friction by engine,

F2 = $$\mu$$R = $$\mu$$mg = 0.2 $$\times$$ 10000 $$\times$$ 9.8

= 1.96 $$\times$$ 104 N

Therefore, the minimum force required by the engine,

F1 + F2 = 4 $$\times$$ 104 + 1.96 $$\times$$ 104 = 5.96 $$\times$$ 104 N

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Given that in a fluorescent lamp's choke, a reverse voltage of 120 V is generated as the choke's current changes steadily from 0.50 A to 0.20 A in a time frame of 0.030 ms. Calculate the self inductance of the choke in millihenrys (mH).
questions.explanation:
Given, reverse voltage, E = 120 V

Change in current, $$\Delta$$I = 0.50 $$-$$ 0.20 = 0.30 A

Time, $$\Delta$$t = 0.030 ms = 0.030 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 s

In an inductor (choke),

Emf induced, $${E_{induced}} = L{{dl} \over {dt}}$$

$$\therefore$$ Self inductance of choke, $$L = {{E \times \Delta t} \over {\Delta I}}$$

$$ = {{120 \times 0.030 \times {{10}^{ - 3}}} \over {0.30}}$$

$$ = 12 \times {10^{ - 3}}$$ H

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If a man becomes a giant, expanding his linear dimensions by a factor of eight, and assuming his density remains unchanged, the factor by which the stress in his legs will increase is
questions.explanation:
Given, linear dimensions increase by a factor of 8.

So, volume will become (8)3 times and area of cross-section will become (8)2 times.

Now, $$stress = {{weight} \over {area}}$$

Weight = (volume $$\times$$ density $$\times$$ g) will also become (8)3 times.

$$\therefore$$ New stress $$ = {{{{(8)}^3} \times {w_0}} \over {{{(8)}^2} \times {A_0}}} = 8\left( {{{{w_0}} \over {{A_0}}}} \right)$$

Hence, the stress increases by a factor of 8.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: When 2 moles of a monoatomic gas are mixed with 3 moles of a diatomic gas, the value of adiabatic exponent for the mixture is
questions.explanation:
Let, $$\gamma$$ be the adiabatic exponent for the mixture.

For monoatomic gas,

n1 = 2 and $$\gamma$$1 = $${{5} \over {3}}$$

For diatomic gas,

n2 = 3 and $$\gamma$$2 = $${{7} \over {5}}$$

For the mixture,

$${{{n_1} + {n_2}} \over {\gamma - 1}} = {{{n_1}} \over {{\gamma _1} - 1}} + {{{n_2}} \over {{\gamma _2} - 1}}$$

Substituting all the given values in above equation, we get

$${{2 + 3} \over {\gamma - 1}} = {2 \over {{5 \over 3} - 1}} + {3 \over {{7 \over 5} - 1}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {5 \over {\gamma - 1}} = {{21} \over 2} \Rightarrow \gamma = {{31} \over {21}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A simple pendulum is placed inside a lift, the lift is moving with a uniform acceleration. If the time periods of the pendulum while the lift is moving upwards and downwards are in the ratio of 1 : 3, then the acceleration of the lift is

[Take acceleration due to gravity, g = 10 m/s2]
questions.explanation:
Let a be the acceleration of the lift.

Given, the ratio of time periods of pendulum while the lift is moving upwards and downwards,

T1 : T2 = 1 : 3

When lift is moving upwards, then total time period,

$${T_1} = 2\pi \sqrt {{I \over {g + a}}} $$........ (i)

When lift is moving downwards, then total time period,

$${T_2} = 2\pi \sqrt {{I \over {g - a}}} $$ ....... (ii)

Dividing Eq. (i) by Eq. (ii), we get

$${{{T_1}} \over {{T_2}}} = \sqrt {{{g - a} \over {g + a}}} \Rightarrow {1 \over 3} = \sqrt {{{g - a} \over {g + a}}} $$

or, $${{g - a} \over {g + a}} = {\left( {{1 \over 3}} \right)^2}$$ or, $${{g - a} \over {g + a}} = {1 \over 9}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 9g - 9a = g + a$$

$$ \Rightarrow 9g - g = 9a + a$$

$$ \Rightarrow 10a = 8g$$

$$a = {{8g} \over {10}} = {{8 \times 10} \over {10}} = 8$$ m/s2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A satellite is moving around the earth with speed v in a circular orbit of radius r. If the orbit radius is decreased by 2%, its speed will increase by
questions.explanation:
As, orbital velocity of a satellite, $$v = \sqrt {{{GM} \over r}} $$

Hence, $$v \propto {1 \over {\sqrt r }}$$

% increase in speed = $${1 \over 2}$$ (% decrease in radius)

$$={1 \over 2}(2\% ) = 1\% $$

Thus, the speed of satellite will increase by 1%.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the circuit shown in figure, the AC source has angular frequency $$\omega$$ = 2000 rad s$$-$$1. The amplitude of the current will be nearest to
questions.explanation:
Given, $$\omega$$ = 2000 rad s$$-$$1

L = 5 mH = 5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 H

C = 50 $$\mu$$F = 50 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$6 F

V = 30 V

Inductive reactance,

XL = $$\omega$$L = 2000 $$\times$$ 5 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 = 10 $$\Omega$$

and capacitive reactance,

$${X_C} = {1 \over {\omega C}} = {1 \over {50 \times {{10}^{ - 6}} \times 2000}} = {{100} \over {10}} = 10\Omega $$

$$\Rightarrow$$ XL = XC

The given circuit is resonant circuit.

Hence, impedance of circuit, Z = R = 4 + 6 + 0.5 = 10.5$$\Omega$$

Amplitude of current, $${I_0} = {V \over Z} = {{30} \over {10.5}} = 2.85$$ A

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The work done by a force acting on a body is as shown in the following graph. The total work done in covering an initial distance of 40 m is
questions.explanation:
Work done, W = area under F-s graph

$$\therefore$$ Total work done is covering an initial distance of 40 m,

W = area of trapezium ABCD + area of trapezium CEFD

$$ = {1 \over 2} \times 20(20 + 30) + {1 \over 2} \times 10 \times (20 + 40) = 800$$ J

[$$\because$$ Area of trapezium = $${1 \over 2}$$ $$\times$$ height $$\times$$ sum of parallel sides]

$$\Rightarrow$$ W = 800 J

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A potentiometer wire, 10 m long, has a resistance of 40$$\Omega$$. It is connected in series with a resistance box and a 4 V storage cell. If the potential gradient along the wire is 0.4 mV cm$$-$$1, the resistance unplugged in the box is
questions.explanation:
Given, potential gradient = 0.4 mV cm$$-$$1

= 0.4 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 V cm$$-$$1

Length of wire, l = 10 m = 1000 cm

Electromagnetic force of cell, E = 4 V

Potential gradient along wire = $${{potential\,difference\,along\,wire} \over {length\,of\,wire}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 0.4 \times {10^{ - 3}} = {{l \times 40} \over {1000}}$$ V cm$$-$$1

Let R be the required resistance unplugged in the box.

$$\therefore$$ Current in wire, $$l = {4 \over {400}}A$$ ...... (i)

Also, $$l = {E \over {R + R'}} = {4 \over {40 + R}}$$ ....... (ii)

Equating Eq. (i) and (ii), we get

$${4 \over {40 + R}} = {4 \over {400}} \Rightarrow R = 400 - 40 = 360\Omega $$
